Commutative Law
A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
Factor Group

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.
Commutative Ring
A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
Finitely Generated Ideal
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.
Factor Ring

Let $R$ be a ring and $\mathfrak{a}$ an ideal in $R$. The factor ring, or residue class ring, $R / \mathfrak{a}$, is defined initially as an abelian group by viewing $\mathfrak{a}$ as a (normal) subgroup of the additive group of $R$. The elements of $R / \mathfrak{a}$ are all residue classes of type $x+\mathfrak{a}$ for $x \in R$, where addition is given by $(x+\mathfrak{a})+(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x+y)+\mathfrak{a}$ and multiplication by $(x+\mathfrak{a}) \cdot(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x \cdot y)+\mathfrak{a}$. The ring properties of $R$ carry over to $R / \mathfrak{a}$.
System of generators
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
Torsion element
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.
Degree of a Field Extension

Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension. The vector space dimension $[L: K]:=\operatorname{dim}_{K} L$ is called the degree of $L$ over $K$. The field extension is called finite or infinite, depending on whether $[L: K]$ is finite or infinite.
Prime Subfield of a Finite Field
The prime subfield of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is the smallest subfield contained within $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$, where $p=\operatorname{char} \\[\mathbb{F}\]>0$.
Center
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Alternating Group

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Domain
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A finitely generated ideal is a specialization of a system of generators because an ideal in a ring that is finitely generated specifically admits a finite system of generators, which is a particular case of the general concept of a system of generators.
